Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Silver Replacement for Conductive Inks
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop new materials to replace silver in conductive ink applications. Current silver replacement materials all have significant drawbacks making them unsuitable for use in many industries which would benefit from these cost savings. The project will utilize advanced thin film nanocoatings to produce silver replacement materials at a low cost while maintaining high performance. These advancements will ultimately allow for the production of lower cost "printable" electronics, as well as decreasing the cost of sophisticated technologies such as photovoltaics.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project directly impacts any sector making use of conductive inks or adhesives in manufacturing of goods. In solar panels, the most important current commercial application, silver inks are used to print conductive traces onto panels. In other areas, conductive inks are gaining new applications daily in everything from computer displays to RFID tags. The value of the silver being used in these applications is roughly $1B/year, and rising consistently. However, current market fluctuations in the cost of silver metal have caused increasing difficulty for manufacturers, with prices of $125/kg in 2003 skyrocketing to $1000/kg in 2012. We anticipate being able to produce silver substitute materials which will increase supply stability and reduce cost in this critical industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF STTR Phase I project addressed a key need in the solar photovoltaic market for lower cost conductive pastes. Currently, the conductive pastes used in solar cell manufacturing cost more than 10% of the total manufacturing cost of a solar cell, and with increasing scale of solar photovoltaic manufacturing margins are increasingly small. The need for reducing the amount of silver used in these conductive pastes is well recognized in industry, with every report including this as a primary goal for the next decade of development. The technology developed here has the potential to reduce this cost from roughly $1000/kg to under $500/kg with a drop in replacement material, which would be equivalent to reducing solar cell manufacturing costs by 5%.

In the course of this project, supercritical fluid deposition was for the first time demonstrated on particles. This unique new thin film deposition technology was used to deposit protective barrier coatings onto copper flake which demonstrated the ability to inhibit oxidation of copper at temperatures of 500°C, a commercially relevant temperature compatible with existing processes. Materials produced were characterized using X-Ray Diffraction, Scanning Electron Microscopy, and X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy to estimate oxidation and surface quality as compared to uncoated copper material. Initial work was done to investigate the conductivity of these materials when incorporated into conductive paste.


Last Modified: 01/06/2015
Modified by: Brian T Neltner

Image
  • This image demonstrates the effectiveness of our new protective coating on copper flake. Both samples were held at 500C for 3 minutes. Left sample is uncoated copper flake, right sample is the same copper flake coated with our barrier material.

    Protective Barrier Coating on Copper Flake
